elements.content: Two new cobalt-diphosphonates templated by protonated 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane (BAPEN), (C8N4H26)0.5·[Co­(HEDP)]·H2O (1) and (C8N4H26)·[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]·5H2O (2), were hydrothermally prepared (HEDP = CH3C­(OH)­(PO3)2, 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate). Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit anionic 1D Co-HEDP chain and 2D Co-HEDP layer structure, respectively. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was realized by adjusting the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction have been studied. Magnetic measurements indicated that the title compounds exhibit weak magnetic interactions. Compounds 1 and 2 feature a proton conductivity of 3.57 × 10–4 and 9.43 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 100% relative humidity and 65 °C, respectively.
elements.clean_text: Two new cobalt-diphosphonates templated by protonated 1,2-bis(3-aminopropylamino)ethane (BAPEN), (C8N4H26)0.5⋅[Co(HEDP)]⋅H2O (1) and (C8N4H26)⋅[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]⋅5H2O (2), were hydrothermally prepared (HEDP = CH3C(OH)(PO3)2, 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate). Compounds 1 and 2 exhibit anionic 1D Co-HEDP chain and 2D Co-HEDP layer structure, respectively. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was realized by adjusting the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction have been studied. Magnetic measurements indicated that the title compounds exhibit weak magnetic interactions. Compounds 1 and 2 feature a proton conductivity of 3.57 × 10-4 and 9.43 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 100% relative humidity and 65 °C, respectively.

elements.content: We report two cobalt-diphosphonates templated by protonated 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was achieved by adjusting the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction are investigated.
elements.clean_text: We report two cobalt-diphosphonates templated by protonated 1,2-bis(3-aminopropylamino)ethane. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was achieved by adjusting the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction are investigated.

elements.content: Metal-phosphonates have attracted huge attention of researchers because of their appealing structures and physicochemical properties. The sound assembly of suitable homometallic (or heterometallic) ions and organophosphonates (from monophosphonate and polyphosphonate to other functionalized phosphonates) generated lots of fascinating products, which offer opportunity for the generation of molecule-based materials with desirable structure (from isolated clusters to chains and coordination network) and properties (catalysis, luminescence, adsorption, magnetism, etc.).
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Metal-phosphonates have attracted huge attention of researchers because of their appealing structures and physicochemical properties. The sound assembly of suitable homometallic (or heterometallic) ions and organophosphonates (from monophosphonate and polyphosphonate to other functionalized phosphonates) generated lots of fascinating products, which offer opportunity for the generation of molecule-based materials with desirable structure (from isolated clusters to chains and coordination network) and properties (catalysis, luminescence, adsorption, magnetism, etc.).

elements.content: The organoamine-directed synthetic strategy is efficient to the fabrication of crystalline materials. The organoamine-directed assembly has been widely investigated in the development history of phosphate and phosphite. The template role together with the potential coordination role of organoamine provides the opportunities for fabricating exotic products in terms of structure and properties. Considering the similarity between inorganic phosphates (or phosphites) and organophosphonates, the organoamines-directed assembly is also applicable to the metal phosphonate. An overview of literature indicated that the early investigated organoamines mainly focus on the small rigid/flexible species, just exampled by heterocyclic amine and aliphatic amine. By contrast, the long aliphatic amine (the total atoms for the chain larger than eight) and large heterocyclic amine (the N-heterocycle larger than three) are relatively less investigated. This is not surprising for several reasons, one of which may be partly due to the fact that such long-chain flexible organic amines are easily decomposed under hydrothermal conditions.
elements.clean_text: The organoamine-directed synthetic strategy is efficient to the fabrication of crystalline materials. The organoamine-directed assembly has been widely investigated in the development history of phosphate and phosphite. The template role together with the potential coordination role of organoamine provides the opportunities for fabricating exotic products in terms of structure and properties. Considering the similarity between inorganic phosphates (or phosphites) and organophosphonates, the organoamines-directed assembly is also applicable to the metal phosphonate. An overview of literature indicated that the early investigated organoamines mainly focus on the small rigid/flexible species, just exampled by heterocyclic amine and aliphatic amine. By contrast, the long aliphatic amine (the total atoms for the chain larger than eight) and large heterocyclic amine (the N-heterocycle larger than three) are relatively less investigated. This is not surprising for several reasons, one of which may be partly due to the fact that such long-chain flexible organic amines are easily decomposed under hydrothermal conditions.

elements.content: We have demonstrated that grafting N-heterocyclic amine to metal-phosphonates would generate a series of novel resulting products. Our previous works mainly focus on metal-phosphonate directed by the rigid N-heterocyclic amine. For example, utilizing the protonated tripyridine moiety as template, we made a 2D zincodiphosphonate with rapid photochromism. Two-layered zinc diphosphonates were produced by utilizing the coordination role and template rule of bipyridine moiety. Two transition metal-triphosphonates layer-pillared by triimidazoe unit have also been synthesized. As continuous a search for new metal-phosphonate, we attempted to, in this work, introduce the long-chain flexible aliphatic amine, 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane (BAPEN), into the cobalt-HEDP ([CH3C­(OH)­(PO3)2], 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate) system (), based on the following considerations: (a) as a multidentate ligand, HEDP has been intensively utilized to generate phosphonates containing captivating structures and/or properties; (b) the cobalt­(II) ion with large single-ion anisotropy is a promising spin carrier for the generation of metal-phosphate bearing fascinating magnetism; (c) the metal-phosphonate is an excellent platform for searching structure with high proton conductivity due to their excellent thermal and chemical stabilities and rich guest–host chemistry.
elements.clean_text: We have demonstrated that grafting N-heterocyclic amine to metal-phosphonates would generate a series of novel resulting products. Our previous works mainly focus on metal-phosphonate directed by the rigid N-heterocyclic amine. For example, utilizing the protonated tripyridine moiety as template, we made a 2D zincodiphosphonate with rapid photochromism. Two-layered zinc diphosphonates were produced by utilizing the coordination role and template rule of bipyridine moiety. Two transition metal-triphosphonates layer-pillared by triimidazoe unit have also been synthesized. As continuous a search for new metal-phosphonate, we attempted to, in this work, introduce the long-chain flexible aliphatic amine, 1,2-bis(3-aminopropylamino)ethane (BAPEN), into the cobalt-HEDP ([CH3C(OH)(PO3)2], 1-hydroxyethylidenediphosphonate) system (), based on the following considerations: (a) as a multidentate ligand, HEDP has been intensively utilized to generate phosphonates containing captivating structures and/or properties; (b) the cobalt(II) ion with large single-ion anisotropy is a promising spin carrier for the generation of metal-phosphate bearing fascinating magnetism; (c) the metal-phosphonate is an excellent platform for searching structure with high proton conductivity due to their excellent thermal and chemical stabilities and rich guest-host chemistry.

elements.clean_text: 1  1,2-Bis(3-aminopropylamino)ethane (BAPEN) and Diphosphonate (HEDP)

elements.content: Herein, we report two protonated BAPEN-directed cobalt-diphosphonates, (C8N4H26)0.5·[Co­(HEDP)]·H2O (1) and (C8N4H26)·[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]·5H2O (2). Compounds 1 and 2 show anionic Co-HEDP chain and Co-HEDP layer structure, respectively. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was observed by mediating the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction are studied.
elements.clean_text: Herein, we report two protonated BAPEN-directed cobalt-diphosphonates, (C8N4H26)0.5⋅[Co(HEDP)]⋅H2O (1) and (C8N4H26)⋅[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]⋅5H2O (2). Compounds 1 and 2 show anionic Co-HEDP chain and Co-HEDP layer structure, respectively. The structure diversities from 1D chain to 2D layer was observed by mediating the synthetic parameters. Their magnetism and proton conduction are studied.

elements.content: All chemicals were analytical grade without additional purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) plot was measured on a SmartLab X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku). Simulated PXRD plot was generated from the corresponding CIF file by Hg-soft. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was measured on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer. Elemental analysis (EA) was measured on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. IR spectroscopy was measured on a MAGNA-560 (Nicolet) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr as pellets. The magnetic data were measured on PPMS DynaCool Cryogen-free System. The diamagnetic corrections were finished with Pascal’s constants. The proton conduction was measured on Solartron 1287 electrochemical interface coupled with 1260 frequency response analyzer. The resistance was simulated from the Nyquist plot. The conductivities were derived from the formula: σ = D/(R S) (D, S, and R represent the thickness, cross-sectional area, and bulk resistance of the sample tablets, respectively).
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

Materials and Physical Measurements

All chemicals were analytical grade without additional purification. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) plot was measured on a SmartLab X-ray diffractometer (Rigaku). Simulated PXRD plot was generated from the corresponding CIF file by Hg-soft. Thermogravimetric (TG) analysis was measured on a Rigaku standard TG-DTA analyzer. Elemental analysis (EA) was measured on a PerkinElmer 240C analyzer. IR spectroscopy was measured on a MAGNA-560 (Nicolet) FT-IR spectrometer with KBr as pellets. The magnetic data were measured on PPMS DynaCool Cryogen-free System. The diamagnetic corrections were finished with Pascal's constants. The proton conduction was measured on Solartron 1287 electrochemical interface coupled with 1260 frequency response analyzer. The resistance was simulated from the Nyquist plot. The conductivities were derived from the formula: σ = D/(R S) (D, S, and R represent the thickness, cross-sectional area, and bulk resistance of the sample tablets, respectively).

elements.content: Compound 1 was obtained by mixing CoCl2 (0.12 g, 0.50 mmol), BAPEN (0.40 mL, 2.18 mmol), HEDP (0.30 mL, 2.11 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h and then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 50% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%)­for C6H19N2O8P2Co (368.10): C, 19.58; H, 5.20; N, 7.61. Found: C, 19.82; H, 5.46; N, 7.23. IR (cm–1): 3408(s), 2972­(m), 2366­(w), 1618(s), 1552­(w), 1474­(w), 1396­(m), 1316­(w), 1274­(w), 1094(s), 962­(w), 886­(w), 806­(m), 666­(m), 596(s), 554­(w).
elements.clean_text:
Preparation of (C8N4H26)0.5⋅[Co(HEDP)]⋅H2O (1)

Compound 1 was obtained by mixing CoCl2 (0.12 g, 0.50 mmol), BAPEN (0.40 mL, 2.18 mmol), HEDP (0.30 mL, 2.11 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h and then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 50% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%)for C6H19N2O8P2Co (368.10): C, 19.58; H, 5.20; N, 7.61. Found: C, 19.82; H, 5.46; N, 7.23. IR (cm-1): 3408(s), 2972(m), 2366(w), 1618(s), 1552(w), 1474(w), 1396(m), 1316(w), 1274(w), 1094(s), 962(w), 886(w), 806(m), 666(m), 596(s), 554(w).

elements.content: Compound 2 was obtained by mixing CoSO4 (0.28 g, 1.00 mmol), BAPEN (0.30 mL, 1.64 mmol), HEDP (0.28 mL, 1.97 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h, then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 65% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%) for C12H48N4O21P4Co2 (826.28): C, 17.44; H, 5.86; N, 6.78. Found: C, 17.72; H, 6.15; N, 6.47. IR (cm–1): 3408(s), 2972­(m), 2366­(w), 1629(s), 1528­(w), 1474­(w), 1402­(w), 1082(s), 946(s), 826(s), 754­(w), 666­(m), 574(s), 474­(m).
elements.clean_text:
(C8N4H26)⋅[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]⋅5H2O (2)

Compound 2 was obtained by mixing CoSO4 (0.28 g, 1.00 mmol), BAPEN (0.30 mL, 1.64 mmol), HEDP (0.28 mL, 1.97 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h, then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 65% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%) for C12H48N4O21P4Co2 (826.28): C, 17.44; H, 5.86; N, 6.78. Found: C, 17.72; H, 6.15; N, 6.47. IR (cm-1): 3408(s), 2972(m), 2366(w), 1629(s), 1528(w), 1474(w), 1402(w), 1082(s), 946(s), 826(s), 754(w), 666(m), 574(s), 474(m).

elements.content: The SCXRD data were collected on a XtaLAB-mini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo–Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. The structures were determined by SHELX-2016 software. The main crystallographic parameters are provided in . CCDC Nos. 1814413 for 1 and 1814414 for 2 contain the full crystallographic data.
elements.clean_text:
Structural Characterization

The SCXRD data were collected on a XtaLAB-mini diffractometer at 293(2) K with Mo-Kα radiation (λ = 0.71073 Å) by ω scan mode. The structures were determined by SHELX-2016 software. The main crystallographic parameters are provided in . CCDC Nos. 1814413 for 1 and 1814414 for 2 contain the full crystallographic data.

Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group of P1̅. There are one crystallographically independent Co atom, one HEDP molecules, half a free protonated organoamine molecule, and one free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All Co atoms are in the [CoO6] octahedral geometry (a), which are offered by five phosphonate oxygen atoms and one hydroxyl oxygen from three symmetry-related HEDP ligands. Each HEDP ligand acts as a chelating-bridging ligand to connect three symmetry-related Co1 atoms. The Co–O bond lengths range from 2.032(4) to 2.258(3) Å. The O–Co–O bond angles are in the scope 77.86(13)–174.15(13)°. The alternating arrangement of Co atoms and HEDP ligand gives rise to the anionic 1D chain of 1 (b) with the protonated organoamine (H4–BAPEN) as charge-balancer. The H4–BAPEN molecules lie in the interchain voids and interact with the chain via H-bonds (N–H···O) (c,d, ).
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Description of Crystal Structure

Compound 1 crystallizes in the space group of P1̅. There are one crystallographically independent Co atom, one HEDP molecules, half a free protonated organoamine molecule, and one free water molecule in the asymmetric unit. All Co atoms are in the [CoO6] octahedral geometry (a), which are offered by five phosphonate oxygen atoms and one hydroxyl oxygen from three symmetry-related HEDP ligands. Each HEDP ligand acts as a chelating-bridging ligand to connect three symmetry-related Co1 atoms. The Co-O bond lengths range from 2.032(4) to 2.258(3) Å. The O-Co-O bond angles are in the scope 77.86(13)-174.15(13)°. The alternating arrangement of Co atoms and HEDP ligand gives rise to the anionic 1D chain of 1 (b) with the protonated organoamine (H4-BAPEN) as charge-balancer. The H4-BAPEN molecules lie in the interchain voids and interact with the chain via H-bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅O) (c,d, ).

elements.content: (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 1. (b) Ball–stick view of 1D chain. The packing structural modes of 1 along b axis (c) and a axis (d).
elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 1. (b) Ball-stick view of 1D chain. The packing structural modes of 1 along b axis (c) and a axis (d).

elements.content: The space group of compound 2 is P21 /c. There are two Co atoms, two HEDP molecules, two coordinated water molecules, one free protonated organoamine molecule, and five lattice water molecules in the asymmetrical unit. Co1 has a hexa-coordinate [CoO6] environment from five phosphonate oxygen atoms and one hydroxyl oxygen from three symmetry-related HEDP ligands, exhibiting a distorted octahedral geometry (a). Co2 also has a hexa-coordinate [CoO6] environment. Four O atoms from two symmetry-related HEDP groups fill the equatorial positions, and two coordinated water molecules occupy the axial positions (a). Each crystallographically independent HEDP unit chelates and bridges Co atoms. HEDP1 containing P1 and P2 atoms connect two independent Co atoms (Co1 and Co2), while HEDP2 containing P3 and P4 atoms connect two symmetry-related Co1 atoms and one Co2 atom. The Co–O bond lengths are in the scope 2.031(3) to 2.325(3) Å. The O–Co–O bond angles range from 76.78(10)–179.21(12)°. The alternating arrangement of Co atoms and HEDP ligand results in a 16-membered ring (16-MR) (b), which acts as a supramolecular building block to form an anionic 2D layer via sharing the phosphonate oxygen (c). The negative charge of the layer is balanced by the protonated organoamine (H4–BAPEN). The H4–BAPEN molecules are located in the pores of 16-MR of the 2D layer and interact with the layer via H-bonds (N–H···O) (d, ).
elements.clean_text: The space group of compound 2 is P21 /c. There are two Co atoms, two HEDP molecules, two coordinated water molecules, one free protonated organoamine molecule, and five lattice water molecules in the asymmetrical unit. Co1 has a hexa-coordinate [CoO6] environment from five phosphonate oxygen atoms and one hydroxyl oxygen from three symmetry-related HEDP ligands, exhibiting a distorted octahedral geometry (a). Co2 also has a hexa-coordinate [CoO6] environment. Four O atoms from two symmetry-related HEDP groups fill the equatorial positions, and two coordinated water molecules occupy the axial positions (a). Each crystallographically independent HEDP unit chelates and bridges Co atoms. HEDP1 containing P1 and P2 atoms connect two independent Co atoms (Co1 and Co2), while HEDP2 containing P3 and P4 atoms connect two symmetry-related Co1 atoms and one Co2 atom. The Co-O bond lengths are in the scope 2.031(3) to 2.325(3) Å. The O-Co-O bond angles range from 76.78(10)-179.21(12)°. The alternating arrangement of Co atoms and HEDP ligand results in a 16-membered ring (16-MR) (b), which acts as a supramolecular building block to form an anionic 2D layer via sharing the phosphonate oxygen (c). The negative charge of the layer is balanced by the protonated organoamine (H4-BAPEN). The H4-BAPEN molecules are located in the pores of 16-MR of the 2D layer and interact with the layer via H-bonds (N-H⋅⋅⋅O) (d, ).

elements.content: (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 2. (b) The 16-MR building units. (c) The 2D layer of 2 composed of 16-MR (organoamines omitted for clarity). (d) The packing structural modes of 2.
elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 2. (b) The 16-MR building units. (c) The 2D layer of 2 composed of 16-MR (organoamines omitted for clarity). (d) The packing structural modes of 2.

elements.content: Although the structural constituents of compounds 1 and 2 are the same (H4–BAPEN as guest, HEDP and Co­(II) as host), they display obviously distinct structural characteristics (1D chain for 1 and 2D layer for 2). The structural modulation from 1D chain to 2D layer was achieved by adjusting the synthetic parameters, which gives us a hint that structural diversities for metal-phosphonate directed by H4–BAPEN may be realized via tuning the synthetic conditions.
elements.clean_text: Although the structural constituents of compounds 1 and 2 are the same (H4-BAPEN as guest, HEDP and Co(II) as host), they display obviously distinct structural characteristics (1D chain for 1 and 2D layer for 2). The structural modulation from 1D chain to 2D layer was achieved by adjusting the synthetic parameters, which gives us a hint that structural diversities for metal-phosphonate directed by H4-BAPEN may be realized via tuning the synthetic conditions.

elements.content: As shown in , compounds 1 and 2 undergo similar multistep weight loss. The first one for 1 (observed: 8.00%) below 140 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules (cal: 5.00%). There is no significant weight loss from 140 to 310 °C. Further heating to about 500 °C leads to the following weight loss (exp: 21.43%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 24.76%). A short-lived platform appears from 500 to 610 °C. Further heating causes the frame to break down. The TG curve of 2 suggests that the first weight loss (exp: 15.82%) below 200 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules (cal: 15.26%). A short-lived platform appears from 200 to 250 °C. Further heating to about 480 °C leads to the second weight loss (exp: 20.30%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 21.58%). Further heating from 610 °C causes the frame to collapse. The peaks of experimental PXRD plots are in agreement with the simulated ones from SCXRD (), indicative of the purity of 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text:
TG and PXRD Analyses

As shown in , compounds 1 and 2 undergo similar multistep weight loss. The first one for 1 (observed: 8.00%) below 140 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules (cal: 5.00%). There is no significant weight loss from 140 to 310 °C. Further heating to about 500 °C leads to the following weight loss (exp: 21.43%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 24.76%). A short-lived platform appears from 500 to 610 °C. Further heating causes the frame to break down. The TG curve of 2 suggests that the first weight loss (exp: 15.82%) below 200 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules (cal: 15.26%). A short-lived platform appears from 200 to 250 °C. Further heating to about 480 °C leads to the second weight loss (exp: 20.30%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 21.58%). Further heating from 610 °C causes the frame to collapse. The peaks of experimental PXRD plots are in agreement with the simulated ones from SCXRD (), indicative of the purity of 1 and 2.

elements.content: All magnetic characterizations were measured on crushed crystalline samples. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility was investigated in the range 2–300 K with a 1000 Oe applied filed. As shown in a, the experimental χM T values of 4.32 and 6.43 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K for 1 and 2 exceed the calculated ones for the unit of noninteracting Co­(II) (1.88 cm3 K mol–1 for 1; 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, with S = 3/2 and g = 2 per Co­(II) ion), which is due to the strong orbital contributions of the octahedral Co­(II) ions. During cooling, the χM T product of 1 and 2 slowly declines from 300 to 50 K, with a rapid decline to the minimum value of 0.16 cm3 K mol–1 for 1 and 1.33 cm3 K mol–1 for 2 at 2 K. The negative Weiss constant θ from Curie–Weiss fitting is −23.33 K for 1 and −10.23 K for 2 (). Notably, the negative θ value could not indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of 1 and 2 because the depopulation of the upper levels during cooling could also contribute to the negative θ value (−20 K) for Co­(II) with octahedral coordination geometry.
elements.clean_text:
Magnetic and Proton Conductivity Studies

All magnetic characterizations were measured on crushed crystalline samples. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility was investigated in the range 2-300 K with a 1000 Oe applied filed. As shown in a, the experimental χM T values of 4.32 and 6.43 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K for 1 and 2 exceed the calculated ones for the unit of noninteracting Co(II) (1.88 cm3 K mol-1 for 1; 3.75 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, with S = 3/2 and g = 2 per Co(II) ion), which is due to the strong orbital contributions of the octahedral Co(II) ions. During cooling, the χM T product of 1 and 2 slowly declines from 300 to 50 K, with a rapid decline to the minimum value of 0.16 cm3 K mol-1 for 1 and 1.33 cm3 K mol-1 for 2 at 2 K. The negative Weiss constant θ from Curie-Weiss fitting is -23.33 K for 1 and -10.23 K for 2 (). Notably, the negative θ value could not indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of 1 and 2 because the depopulation of the upper levels during cooling could also contribute to the negative θ value (-20 K) for Co(II) with octahedral coordination geometry.

elements.content: Curves of χM T vs T (a) and M vs H (b) for 1 and 2. Variable-temperature Nyquist plots for 1 (c) and 2 (d) with 100% relative humidity.
elements.clean_text: 3  Curves of χM T vs T (a) and M vs H (b) for 1 and 2. Variable-temperature Nyquist plots for 1 (c) and 2 (d) with 100% relative humidity.

elements.content: The variable-field magnetization (M) characterizations were investigated in the range 0–5 T at 2 K (b). The plots of M vs H show a quasi-linear increase with the increasing fields. For 1, the M value is 2.13 Nβ at 2 K and 5 T, lower than the calculated one of 3.00 Nβ for one Co­(II) with g = 2 and S = 3/2 (agreeing with the value of 2.17 Nβ calculated for one Co­(II) with g av = 13/3 and S eff = 1/2 per Co­(II) at 2 K). For 2, the M value is 4.30 Nβ at 2 K and 5 T, smaller than the calculated one of 6.00 Nβ for two Co­(II) with g = 2 and S = 3/2 (agreeing with the value of 4.33 Nβ calculated for two Co­(II) with g av = 13/3 and S eff = 1/2 per Co­(II) at 2 K). All these information (the shape of the χM T–T and M–H plots and M value at 5 T and 2 K) indicate that compounds 1 and 2 exhibit weak magnetic interaction. Notably, the S-shape of the M vs H plot of 1 implies the potential metamagnetism. The first derivative of M vs H (dM/dH vs H) indicates the critical filed is about 27500 Oe (or 2.75 T), which is further testified by the field-dependent magnetic susceptibility (). To further investigate the magnetic dynamics of 1 and 2, the frequency- and temperature-dependent ac susceptibilities were studied under a zero direct current field and a 5 Oe ac magnetic field (). There are no evident variable-frequency ac signals below 20 K for 1 and 2.
elements.clean_text: The variable-field magnetization (M) characterizations were investigated in the range 0-5 T at 2 K (b). The plots of M vs H show a quasi-linear increase with the increasing fields. For 1, the M value is 2.13 Nβ at 2 K and 5 T, lower than the calculated one of 3.00 Nβ for one Co(II) with g = 2 and S = 3/2 (agreeing with the value of 2.17 Nβ calculated for one Co(II) with g av = 13/3 and S eff = 1/2 per Co(II) at 2 K). For 2, the M value is 4.30 Nβ at 2 K and 5 T, smaller than the calculated one of 6.00 Nβ for two Co(II) with g = 2 and S = 3/2 (agreeing with the value of 4.33 Nβ calculated for two Co(II) with g av = 13/3 and S eff = 1/2 per Co(II) at 2 K). All these information (the shape of the χM T-T and M-H plots and M value at 5 T and 2 K) indicate that compounds 1 and 2 exhibit weak magnetic interaction. Notably, the S-shape of the M vs H plot of 1 implies the potential metamagnetism. The first derivative of M vs H (dM/dH vs H) indicates the critical filed is about 27500 Oe (or 2.75 T), which is further testified by the field-dependent magnetic susceptibility (). To further investigate the magnetic dynamics of 1 and 2, the frequency- and temperature-dependent ac susceptibilities were studied under a zero direct current field and a 5 Oe ac magnetic field (). There are no evident variable-frequency ac signals below 20 K for 1 and 2.

elements.content: The protonated organoamine (H4–BAPEN) in 1 and 2 can serve as proton carriers. For 1, H4–BAPEN forms an H-bond with the diphosphonate oxygen, and the guest water forms an H-bond with the hydroxyl oxygen of diphosphonate (). For 2, H4–BAPEN forms an H-bond with the diphosphonate oxygen and the guest water (), and an H-bond us also observable between the guest water. The H-bonds for guest–guest and host–guest are important for proton conduction. Thus, proton conduction of compounds 1 and 2 has been investigated by alternating current (ac) impedance spectroscopy. Compounds 1 and 2 nearly have no conductivity at ambient conditions, which may be due to the lack of efficient path for proton conduction. When disposing them in a closed chamber containing saturated water vapor for 3 days, the conductivity becomes 8.49 × 10–5 and 1.93 × 10–5 S cm–1. The impedance as a function of temperature of 1 and 2 have been measured (c,d). The conductivity increases with the elevating temperature and reaches 3.57 × 10–4 and 9.43 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 65 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. This temperature-dependent property indicates 1 and 2 can be candidates for temperature sensor. Notably, the difference of conductivity between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the difference of crystal structure and hydrogen bonding network. This inspires us to design and regulate topology of the hydrogen bonding network within the metal-phosphonates through crystal engineering. After proton-conducting characterizations, the PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree with the simulated ones (), proving the structural stability during the process of measurement.
elements.clean_text: The protonated organoamine (H4-BAPEN) in 1 and 2 can serve as proton carriers. For 1, H4-BAPEN forms an H-bond with the diphosphonate oxygen, and the guest water forms an H-bond with the hydroxyl oxygen of diphosphonate (). For 2, H4-BAPEN forms an H-bond with the diphosphonate oxygen and the guest water (), and an H-bond us also observable between the guest water. The H-bonds for guest-guest and host-guest are important for proton conduction. Thus, proton conduction of compounds 1 and 2 has been investigated by alternating current (ac) impedance spectroscopy. Compounds 1 and 2 nearly have no conductivity at ambient conditions, which may be due to the lack of efficient path for proton conduction. When disposing them in a closed chamber containing saturated water vapor for 3 days, the conductivity becomes 8.49 × 10-5 and 1.93 × 10-5 S cm-1. The impedance as a function of temperature of 1 and 2 have been measured (c,d). The conductivity increases with the elevating temperature and reaches 3.57 × 10-4 and 9.43 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 65 °C for 1 and 2, respectively. This temperature-dependent property indicates 1 and 2 can be candidates for temperature sensor. Notably, the difference of conductivity between 1 and 2 may be attributed to the difference of crystal structure and hydrogen bonding network. This inspires us to design and regulate topology of the hydrogen bonding network within the metal-phosphonates through crystal engineering. After proton-conducting characterizations, the PXRD patterns of 1 and 2 agree with the simulated ones (), proving the structural stability during the process of measurement.

elements.content: Two cobalt-diphosphonates supported by protonated 1,2-bis­(3-aminopropylamino)­ethane (BAPEN) were prepared and studied. Anionic 1D chain and 2D layer structure are observed in compounds 1 and 2, respectively, and the structural modulation from 1D chain to 2D layer was realized by tuning the synthetic parameters. Systematic research and use of long-chain flexible organoamines acting as templates in this family, to the best of knowledge, are still their infancy. Their magnetism and proton conduction are investigated. Magnetic measurements indicated that the intrachain and intralayer Co­(II) ions for 1 and 2 feature weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Compounds 1 and 2 show a proton conductivity of 3.57 × 10–4 and 9.43 × 10–5 S cm–1 at 100% RH and 65 °C, respectively. This work highlights the template role of long aliphatic amine in the synthesis of metal-phosphonates. Expanding this synthetic method to other metal-phosphonates is underway, aiming at synthesizing novel crystalline metal-phosphonate materials.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

Two cobalt-diphosphonates supported by protonated 1,2-bis(3-aminopropylamino)ethane (BAPEN) were prepared and studied. Anionic 1D chain and 2D layer structure are observed in compounds 1 and 2, respectively, and the structural modulation from 1D chain to 2D layer was realized by tuning the synthetic parameters. Systematic research and use of long-chain flexible organoamines acting as templates in this family, to the best of knowledge, are still their infancy. Their magnetism and proton conduction are investigated. Magnetic measurements indicated that the intrachain and intralayer Co(II) ions for 1 and 2 feature weak antiferromagnetic coupling. Compounds 1 and 2 show a proton conductivity of 3.57 × 10-4 and 9.43 × 10-5 S cm-1 at 100% RH and 65 °C, respectively. This work highlights the template role of long aliphatic amine in the synthesis of metal-phosphonates. Expanding this synthetic method to other metal-phosphonates is underway, aiming at synthesizing novel crystalline metal-phosphonate materials.

cln_elements.content:
Compound 1 was obtained by mixing CoCl2 (0.12 g, 0.50 mmol), BAPEN (0.40 mL, 2.18 mmol), HEDP (0.30 mL, 2.11 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h and then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 50% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%)­for C6H19N2O8P2Co (368.10): C, 19.58; H, 5.20; N, 7.61. Found: C, 19.82; H, 5.46; N, 7.23. IR (cm–1): 3408(s), 2972­(m), 2366­(w), 1618(s), 1552­(w), 1474­(w), 1396­(m), 1316­(w), 1274­(w), 1094(s), 962­(w), 886­(w), 806­(m), 666­(m), 596(s), 554­(w).

(C<sub>8</sub>N<sub>4</sub>H<sub>26</sub>)·[Co<sub>2</sub>(HEDP)<sub>2</sub>(H<sub>2</sub>O)<sub>2</sub>]·5H<sub>2</sub>O (<bold>2</bold>)

Compound 2 was obtained by mixing CoSO4 (0.28 g, 1.00 mmol), BAPEN (0.30 mL, 1.64 mmol), HEDP (0.28 mL, 1.97 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h, then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 65% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%) for C12H48N4O21P4Co2 (826.28): C, 17.44; H, 5.86; N, 6.78. Found: C, 17.72; H, 6.15; N, 6.47. IR (cm–1): 3408(s), 2972­(m), 2366­(w), 1629(s), 1528­(w), 1474­(w), 1402­(w), 1082(s), 946(s), 826(s), 754­(w), 666­(m), 574(s), 474­(m).
cln_elements.clean_text:
Preparation of (C8N4H26)0.5⋅[Co(HEDP)]⋅H2O (1)

Compound 1 was obtained by mixing CoCl2 (0.12 g, 0.50 mmol), BAPEN (0.40 mL, 2.18 mmol), HEDP (0.30 mL, 2.11 mmol), and H2O (8 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h and then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 50% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%)for C6H19N2O8P2Co (368.10): C, 19.58; H, 5.20; N, 7.61. Found: C, 19.82; H, 5.46; N, 7.23. IR (cm-1): 3408(s), 2972(m), 2366(w), 1618(s), 1552(w), 1474(w), 1396(m), 1316(w), 1274(w), 1094(s), 962(w), 886(w), 806(m), 666(m), 596(s), 554(w).

(C8N4H26)⋅[Co2(HEDP)2(H2O)2]⋅5H2O (2)

Compound 2 was obtained by mixing CoSO4 (0.28 g, 1.00 mmol), BAPEN (0.30 mL, 1.64 mmol), HEDP (0.28 mL, 1.97 mmol), and H2O (10 mL) in an 25 mL Teflon-lined autoclave, and heating at 145 °C for 120 h, then cooling to room temperature. Yield: ca. 65% based on HEDP. Theoretical EA (%) for C12H48N4O21P4Co2 (826.28): C, 17.44; H, 5.86; N, 6.78. Found: C, 17.72; H, 6.15; N, 6.47. IR (cm-1): 3408(s), 2972(m), 2366(w), 1629(s), 1528(w), 1474(w), 1402(w), 1082(s), 946(s), 826(s), 754(w), 666(m), 574(s), 474(m).

cln_elements.content:
As shown in , compounds 1 and 2 undergo similar multistep weight loss. The first one for 1 (observed: 8.00%) below 140 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules (cal: 5.00%). There is no significant weight loss from 140 to 310 °C. Further heating to about 500 °C leads to the following weight loss (exp: 21.43%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 24.76%). A short-lived platform appears from 500 to 610 °C. Further heating causes the frame to break down. The TG curve of 2 suggests that the first weight loss (exp: 15.82%) below 200 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules (cal: 15.26%). A short-lived platform appears from 200 to 250 °C. Further heating to about 480 °C leads to the second weight loss (exp: 20.30%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 21.58%). Further heating from 610 °C causes the frame to collapse. The peaks of experimental PXRD plots are in agreement with the simulated ones from SCXRD (), indicative of the purity of 1 and 2.

Magnetic and Proton Conductivity Studies

All magnetic characterizations were measured on crushed crystalline samples. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility was investigated in the range 2–300 K with a 1000 Oe applied filed. As shown in a, the experimental χM T values of 4.32 and 6.43 cm3 K mol–1 at 300 K for 1 and 2 exceed the calculated ones for the unit of noninteracting Co­(II) (1.88 cm3 K mol–1 for 1; 3.75 cm3 K mol–1 for 2, with S = 3/2 and g = 2 per Co­(II) ion), which is due to the strong orbital contributions of the octahedral Co­(II) ions. During cooling, the χM T product of 1 and 2 slowly declines from 300 to 50 K, with a rapid decline to the minimum value of 0.16 cm3 K mol–1 for 1 and 1.33 cm3 K mol–1 for 2 at 2 K. The negative Weiss constant θ from Curie–Weiss fitting is −23.33 K for 1 and −10.23 K for 2 (). Notably, the negative θ value could not indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of 1 and 2 because the depopulation of the upper levels during cooling could also contribute to the negative θ value (−20 K) for Co­(II) with octahedral coordination geometry.

TG and PXRD Analyses

There is no significant weight loss from 140 to 310 °C. Further heating to about 500 °C leads to the following weight loss (exp: 21.43%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 24.76%). A short-lived platform appears from 500 to 610 °C. Further heating causes the frame to break down. The TG curve of 2 suggests that the first weight loss (exp: 15.82%) below 200 °C was due to the loss of free water molecules and coordinated water molecules (cal: 15.26%). A short-lived platform appears from 200 to 250 °C. Further heating to about 480 °C leads to the second weight loss (exp: 20.30%) because of the combustion of protonated BAPEN (cal: 21.58%). Further heating from 610 °C causes the frame to collapse. The peaks of experimental PXRD plots are in agreement with the simulated ones from SCXRD (), indicative of the purity of 1 and 2.

Magnetic and Proton Conductivity Studies

All magnetic characterizations were measured on crushed crystalline samples. The variable-temperature magnetic susceptibility was investigated in the range 2-300 K with a 1000 Oe applied filed. As shown in a, the experimental χM T values of 4.32 and 6.43 cm3 K mol-1 at 300 K for 1 and 2 exceed the calculated ones for the unit of noninteracting Co(II) (1.88 cm3 K mol-1 for 1; 3.75 cm3 K mol-1 for 2, with S = 3/2 and g = 2 per Co(II) ion), which is due to the strong orbital contributions of the octahedral Co(II) ions. During cooling, the χM T product of 1 and 2 slowly declines from 300 to 50 K, with a rapid decline to the minimum value of 0.16 cm3 K mol-1 for 1 and 1.33 cm3 K mol-1 for 2 at 2 K. The negative Weiss constant θ from Curie-Weiss fitting is -23.33 K for 1 and -10.23 K for 2 (). Notably, the negative θ value could not indicate the antiferromagnetic behavior of 1 and 2 because the depopulation of the upper levels during cooling could also contribute to the negative θ value (-20 K) for Co(II) with octahedral coordination geometry.

(a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 1. (b) Ball–stick view of 1D chain. The packing structural modes of 1 along b axis (c) and a axis (d).
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 1. (b) Ball-stick view of 1D chain. The packing structural modes of 1 along b axis (c) and a axis (d).

cln_elements.content: (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 2. (b) The 16-MR building units. (c) The 2D layer of 2 composed of 16-MR (organoamines omitted for clarity). (d) The packing structural modes of 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  (a) Coordination modes of Co ions in 2. (b) The 16-MR building units. (c) The 2D layer of 2 composed of 16-MR (organoamines omitted for clarity). (d) The packing structural modes of 2.

cln_elements.content: Curves of χM T vs T (a) and M vs H (b) for 1 and 2. Variable-temperature Nyquist plots for 1 (c) and 2 (d) with 100% relative humidity.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Curves of χM T vs T (a) and M vs H (b) for 1 and 2. Variable-temperature Nyquist plots for 1 (c) and 2 (d) with 100% relative humidity.

metadata.title:
Two Cobalt-diphosphonates Templated by Long-Chain
Flexible Amines: Synthesis, Structures, Proton Conductivity, and Magnetic
Properties
